all_paragraphs: Here, I want to argue that sometimes data scientists have to go beyond the data and the science. Often there isn’t time to wait for enough data to come in to make a rational prediction of potential outcomes. Sometimes we just have to start something. In these cases there are some non-scientific tools to help us make reasonable predictions that are at least better than nothing.

In about 550 BC, Croesus the king of Lydia, made an offering to the Oracle of Delphi that reinforced his legendary reputation for wealth. There were ingots that would form a pedestal for a quarter-tonne golden statue, two giant urns, one gold, one silver urn, and various other precious items: a five foot high golden statue of the cook who had saved him from poisoning, and his wife’s jewellery and girdles. It is unrecorded what his wife thought about it.

In return, he asked the Oracle to predict what would happen if he should attack Persia. He was told that if he did so a mighty empire would fall. Interpreting this as a sign that he would conquer — he’d spent all that money after all — he invaded. The Oracle was duly proved right. A mighty empire did fall. Unfortunately for Croesus it was his own [1].
It turns out that predicting the future is a tricky thing.

I think we can safely say that Croesus didn’t get his money back. The risk for us data scientists is that we act like the Oracle. People pay us to tell them what’s going to happen, but then, when push comes to shove, we often respond with “degrees of belief” and abstruse lectures about probabilities. Now don’t get me wrong, I personally love a discussion about the interpretation of a probability, but I wonder if we sound to outsiders like the priests at Delphi.
“Thank you for the paycheck, here’s some mystically ambiguous woo-woo, hope it makes you feel good. Now run along and do what you were going to do anyway”
This is unsustainable, and could easily lead to people giving up on data science altogether.
The other day, I watched a close colleague tell a client that data scientists didn’t make predictions. Since I’ve seen him call many a .predict() method, I couldn’t really understand what he meant.

Afterwards, his argument was that when a client hears the word prediction, they think that we’re making definitive statements about the way the world is going to be. He prefers the word forecast, because people understand that weather forecasts aren’t ever going to be 100% accurate.

Now he may well be right about clients’ perceptions (he usually is). However, for me, this is a distinction without a difference. I think, mostly, data scientists do, in fact, use a bunch of scientific tools to make predictions. Sometimes, e.g. in a time series problem, this is obvious: tomorrow sell these shares because we think their value will go down over time. Other times it’s less obvious: e.g. in a classification problem. You might not be predicting the future, per se, but the problem has you predicting what human judges would label the examples you’re classifying.

There are a few exceptions to this — e.g. some type of GANs might not count. But by and large, I’d argue that most of us are making predictions about events that are going to happen, or that have already happened but haven’t yet been observed by us.
There’s nothing wrong with this. We should embrace it. It’s what scientists do.

The cartoon explanation of the scientific method is that scientists build a model and then go out and seek evidence that disproves it. Gradually, as more evidence is gathered and the model isn’t shown to be wrong, the model gets accepted as a scientific truth [2]. This is roughly how data scientists claim to behave: they look at some data, build a model that captures what’s going on, then launch that model live. As more data comes in, the model is proven.

Unfortunately, in many real world cases, our predictions just aren’t very good! For example, even knowing that a potential customer has previously got halfway through a purchase process — which seems like it should be a massive indicator of intent — only provides a marginal improvement in predicting who will click on an ad. And if I could predict which shares would go down tomorrow, I’d be writing this blog from a yacht in the Mediterranean, not a flat in a London suburb.

Our techniques are such that we count doing a little bit better than random chance as a win. And if we can also do a tiny bit better than the competition, we’re in business. We’re using the scientific method as best we can but are running into limitations in the methods and technology.

Now, there’s a kind of data scientist who argues that we should stop when the science stops. In this argument, the scientific method is the pinnacle of human achievement when it comes to saying anything about the future. When we can’t use it to say anything meaningful, it means we can’t really know anything. And whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent [3].

As someone trained as a scientist, I have some sympathy for this line of thought. However the world just doesn’t work that way! If your company is moving at science speed, i.e. slowly and deliberatively, moving forward only when enough evidence has accumulated, you will surely be out-competed by companies that are moving faster.

But, our data scientist might argue, these companies are proceeding by guesswork! They’ll surely fail eventually. Well this might be true, but there are two counter arguments to this. One is that it’s a very big world and eventually can be a very long time. With a hundred competitors, some of them will guess right just by chance. And they’re moving so much quicker than you that you’ve been out-competed before you can gather the data that proves whether the guess is right.

However there’s another more interesting reason. I’d argue that guesswork isn’t necessarily random. It is possible to guess and do better than chance, and there exist rational, but essentially non-scientific tools, that help us do it.

The trade-off then is to wait until the data is in and proceed with some degree of certainty, or to use non-scientific tools to make an educated guess. In many cases, I’d argue that organisations should take the latter approach.

So far I’ve argued that as scientists, we are asked to predict the future but are basically unable to do it. There are two responses to this. One is to throw your hands up and say, “I’m a scientist, here’s where I stop” and watch while you’re out-competed. The other is to leave science behind and try and make sense of a complex world using other tools.

So what are these tools? Well here are some, borrowed from the field of Future Studies [4]. To an audience of data scientists they might seem alien. What we’re setting out to do is imagine a range of semi-plausible futures and then assign them probabilities. Here I mean probability in the gambler’s sense of “degree of belief”. Happily, this turns out to also be the Bayesian sense of probability. If you’re skeptical, remember there’s more to human endeavour than science. Hamlet is in some sense true, even though it’s not “literally true”.

Tool 1: Sci-fi envisioning. Here, you just sit back and make semi-plausible stuff up, almost without constraint. The idea is to let your mind go. Space elevators? Why not! Undersea colonies? Sure! Perhaps something darker? Total population surveillance by private companies. That’s sci-fi, right?

The use for this tool is not to produce realistic ideas. It’s to let go of the constraints provided by our data driven training and just let the imagination rip. If, like me, you reached Iain M. Banks via Clarke and Asimov, you can channel those future visions to make the whole process less … odd.

Tool 2: Horizon scanning. The future is already here — It’s just not very evenly distributed [5]. The history of innovation is full of examples of ideas spreading out of niches and taking over the world. Those guys in Canada, still studying neural-nets as late as 2010? That was going nowhere, right up until it was going everywhere. So what else is out there? A.I. in China probably counts as mainstream, but what about nano-materials in Japan? What data science innovations are taking place in Bangalore? Or urban design innovations in Lagos? And this isn’t limited to technology. Think of the cultural dynamism of Central African musicians, rapping in Franglish [6].
The point is that the future might well exist somewhere already. A prediction that involves an existing innovation spreading is more plausible than one that occurs ab initio.

Tool 3: Trends. OK, just making stuff up is only going to get us so far. We have to look at data to connect an imagined future with our existing present. You might have all these mad ideas, but can we tell if any of them, in any way, are realistic? Well one way to do this is to pick some relevant trends in the data and extrapolate them. Remember that space elevator? Well how quickly are improvements in the tensile strength of nano-materials coming?

This often gets described as the scientific part of Future Studies. For a data scientist it probably doesn’t count as Science. But at least the process of looking at trends in the data should feel familiar. It’s just that picking the data is an art. You can’t construct a factor model of everything, but that doesn’t mean you can do nothing. Remember we’re talking about degrees of belief here.

Tool 4: Scenario testing. To anyone that’s worked in finance this should be familiar. It’s the kind of stress-testing that the people who manage risk do all the time (or at least since 2008/9). In their case, they limit their investigation to the effect of events on financial portfolios, e.g. what could happen to stock prices, if say, the US withdraws from the WTO, or to commodities prices if terrorism blocks the Malacca straits? Similarly, we can think about the effects big events would have on our predictions, e.g. what effect would a war in the South China Sea have on a prediction that Japan will build the first space elevator? The point is that no single big-effect event is very likely, but something will happen eventually. By investigating a bunch of events, hopefully you can detect common themes that would effect your prediction in a similar manner.

Synthesis. You’ll probably bounce around refining your prediction using each of these tools in turn. By the end, you’ll have imagined a bunch of futures, investigated a bunch of innovations around the world and attempted to disprove them with trends and hypothesised scenarios. However when the music stops, you have to stop dancing. Remember we’re not doing science here. You have to come down and use your judgement to decide. If you prefer you can think of it as having a prior belief in what’s going to happen that you’ve updated with weak evidence. The trouble is, you don’t know how weak that evidence is, so Maths isn’t going to help you.

As a final word, I need to mention how this fits in with the work of Philip Tetlock and his work on the Good Judgement Project [7]. This is a competition that measures how good people are at predicting the future. He’s identified a subgroup of super-forecasters that are better at predicting the future than their contemporaries. He goes on to identify character traits that make them good: basically be smart and open minded, hang out with other smart and open minded people, work hard, develop an intuition about what probability means, and account for your biases [8].

This is all good stuff, but doesn’t give an account of what to do if you are faced with having to make a prediction. Work hard? Sure, but at what? However I was relieved to read that when super-forecasters describe how they make their predictions, they give two of the methods detailed above [9].

So in conclusion, I’m arguing that data scientists can’t just ignore the prediction problem, since that’s what people are paying us for. However we need to face the fact that the tools we have to make predictions aren’t very good. Sometimes “not very good” is good enough. However in circumstances where it isn’t, and where we need to think about a longer term future, there exist other non-scientific tools for us to use.
What do you think? Should data scientists leave predictions alone? Let me know in the comments!

[2] This is of course a simplification of Karl Popper, see here for a discussion. Popper himself also had a concept of “Corroboration” of a model which was jumped on by statisticians associated with Likelihood methods. Of course there’s Kuhn too, so you see why mine is the cartoon version.
[3] Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus, 7, Ludwig Wittgenstein
[4] These tools are taken from my notes on a lecture by Professor Peter Madden at the Future Cities Catapult. Any mistakes are mine!
[5] Quote by William Gibson, exact place, as ever, disputed.
[7] References to the Good Judgement Project can be found here.

[8] Identifying and cultivating superforecasters as a method of improving probabilistic predictions. Barbara A. Mellers, Philip Tetlock. Perspectives on psychological science, Vol 10, No. 3, pages 267–81
[9] The methods referenced here include, I’d argue, Trends (nuclear testing in Korea) and Scenario Testing (death in the South China Sea).
